Suppose we have a system of congruences with different moduli:

\begin{gather} x ≡ b_1 \bmod n_1 \\ x ≡ b_2 \bmod n_2 \\ \vdots \\ x ≡ b_k \bmod n_k \end{gather}

And suppose \((n_i, n_j) = 1\) whenever \(i \ne j\). This means all pairs of \(n\) are coprime. Let \(N = n_1n_2 \ldots n_k\), let \(N_i = \frac{N}{n_i}\) and let \(N_i^{-1}\) be the inverse of \(N_i\) modulo \(n_i\). The solution of the congruences is:

$$ x = N_1N_1^{-1}b_1 + N_2N_2^{-1}b_2 + \ldots + N_kN_k^{-1}b_k $$

Find the least nonnegative solution for this system of congruences:

\begin{gather} x ≡ 2 \bmod 3 \\ x ≡ 1 \bmod 4 \\ x ≡ 3 \bmod 5 \end{gather}

Let \(N = (3)(4)(5) = 60\), \(N_1 = 20\), \(N_2 = 15\) and \(N_3 = 12\). There exists inverses \(N_i^{-1}\):

\begin{gather} 20 N_1^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 3 \implies N_1^{-1} = 2 \\ 15 N_2^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 4 \implies N_2^{-1} = 3 \\ 12 N_3^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 5 \implies N_3^{-1} = 3\end{gather}

So the solution is \(x = N_1N_1^{-1} (2) + N_2N_2^{-1} (1) + N_3N_3^{-1} (3) = 233 \). This means least nonnegtaive solution mod \(N\) would be \(x = 53\).

Find the least nonnegative solution for this system of congruences:

\begin{gather} x ≡ 1 \bmod 7 \\ x ≡ 4 \bmod 6 \\ x ≡ 3 \bmod 5 \end{gather}

Let \(N = (7)(6)(5) = 210\), \(N_1 = 30\), \(N_2 = 35\) and \(N_3 = 42\). There exists inverses \(N_i^{-1}\):

\begin{gather} 30 N_1^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 7 \implies N_1^{-1} = 4 \\ 35 N_2^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 6 \implies N_2^{-1} = 5 \\ 42 N_3^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 5 \implies N_3^{-1} = 3\end{gather}

So the solution is \(x = N_1N_1^{-1} (1) + N_2N_2^{-1} (4) + N_3N_3^{-1} (3) = 1198 \). This means least nonnegtaive solution mod \(N\) would be \(x = 148\).
